title: 1821 Japanese Sangaku
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/xG6JlSH1RF-sangaku-c-080118.jpg?width=1200"}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Given a right triangle of sides "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3, 4, 5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", a blue ellipse is inscribed, tangent to all three sides, with its major axis parallel with the hypotenuse.  Three identical red circles are inscribed, two of them inside the blue ellipse and tangent to each other, the third tangent to the blue ellipse also, but tangent to the two shorter sides of the triangle.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the diameter "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"D"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of the identical red circles, which is slightly greater than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  Enter your answer as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left\lfloor 1000D \right\rfloor"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"See "},{"type":"text","text":"Geometry Beyond Algebra","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Using the notation of the referred-to paper, we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c=4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"h = \frac{c^2-b^2}{2a}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k = \frac{bc}{a}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m = \frac{b}{c}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\beta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the semi-major axis of the ellipse, then the coordinates "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x_0,y_0)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of the centre of the ellipse are given by
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x_0 \; = \; \frac{k(h-2\beta)}{h-\beta} \hspace{2cm} y_0 \; = \; h - \beta "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
while the semi-major axis "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of the ellipse, and its eccentricity "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are given by
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \alpha \; = \; \frac{1}{m}\sqrt{(mx_0 - y_0)^2 - \beta^2} \hspace{2cm} e \; =\; \sqrt{\frac{(mx_0 - y_0)^2 - (m^2+1)\beta^2}{(mx_0 - y_0)^2 - \beta^2}} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" 
while the radius of the three circles is
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" r \; = \; e\beta "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
while the coordinates of the centre of the bottom circle are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x_1,y_1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x_1 \; = \; \frac{r(c-b)}{a} \hspace{2cm} y_1 \; = \; \frac{r(c+b)}{a} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" 
These conditions (for a suitable range of values of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\beta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":") ensure that the ellipse is tangent to all three sides of the triangle, and that the two circles of radius "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are mutually tangent, and both tangent to the ellipse, and also that the bottom circle is tangent to the bottom two sides of the triangle. We now need to choose "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\beta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" so that the bottom circle is tangent to the ellipse. The important point is that all the parameters of the problem have been expressed in terms of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\beta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a,b,c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"). There is only one degree of freedom for any right-angled triangle."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"My aim is to find a way of solving this problem that does not descend into the involved manipulation of three different quartics required in the paper. If a simpler approach can be found, a numerical solution will be relatively easy."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We want to determine the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\beta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that the shortest distance from the ellipse "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{x^2}{\alpha^2} + \frac{y^2}{\beta^2} = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to the point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x_0-x_1,y_0-y_1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Applying the method of Lagrange multipliers, the shortest distance from the point to the ellipse is equal to
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" X \; = \; \sqrt{\frac{\lambda^2(x_0-x_1)^2}{(\alpha^2 + \lambda)^2} + \frac{\lambda^2(y_0-y_1)^2}{(\beta^2 + \lambda)^2}} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" 
where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lambda"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the positive value such that
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{\alpha^2(x_0-x_1)^2}{(\alpha^2 + \lambda)^2} + \frac{\beta^2(y_0-y_1)^2}{(\beta^2 + \lambda)^2} = 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
(the maximum distance from the point to the ellipse is obtained by finding the negative solution of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lambda"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":")."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The equation "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X = r"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can be solved numerically, and we obtain "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\beta =  0.5631982331252968"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha = 1.8144501500345467"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e = 0.950607314800319"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r = 0.5353803600915225"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"D = 1.070760720183045"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lfloor 1000 D\rfloor = \boxed{1070}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                            Thank you."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Well, to be fair, the paper is about finding alebraic solutions. The whole TOP business is, of course, just a matter of finding polynomial remainders lots of times."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"My formula for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lambda"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a quartic, and quartics have exact solutions. It might be interesting to try to find the exact expression for the key value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lambda"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and hence an explicit expression for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" X"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in terms of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\beta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". That is for another day, perhaps...

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The major and minor axes of the blue ellipse works out to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"   1.814450150...              "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0.563198233...  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Edit:  After seeing Mark's posted numbers, I pushed my approximation to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"D=1.070760720183043..."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Refer to the figure below, showing a right triangle of sides in proportions of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3, 4, 5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", a blue ellipse centered at the origin "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(0,0)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and red and green unit circles.  The center of the green unit circle is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x_0,y_0)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  The major axis of the blue ellipse is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" while the minor axis is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"pq"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  Then if the blue ellipse is tangent to the right triangle, the red unit circles tangent to it and each other, and the green unit circle is tangent to the right triangle, then the following must be true"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p=\dfrac { 1 }{ q\sqrt { 1-{ q }^{ 2 } }  }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x_0=\dfrac { 1 }{ 5 } +\dfrac { 1 }{ 25q\sqrt { 1-{ q }^{ 2 } }  } \left( \dfrac { 27+48q^{ 2 } }{ \sqrt { 9+16{ q }^{ 2 } }  } -\dfrac { 64+36q^{ 2 } }{ \sqrt { 16+9{ q }^{ 2 } }  }  \right)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y_0=-\dfrac { 7 }{ 5 } +\dfrac { 1 }{ 25q\sqrt { 1-{ q }^{ 2 } }  } \left( \dfrac { 48+27q^{ 2 } }{ \sqrt { 16+9{ q }^{ 2 } }  } +\dfrac { 36+64q^{ 2 } }{ \sqrt { 9+16{ q }^{ 2 } }  }  \right)
"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/hRaavWuMqC-sangaku-sol-080518.jpg?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Then we solve the following simple equation for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y_0-\sqrt{1-(x-x_0)^2}=q\sqrt{p^2-x^2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"...and that's when things explode.  But "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can still be worked out, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q = 0.310396090581256029"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is how bad it gets when it's done this way.   Let "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=\left(q^2-1\right)^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=\dfrac{4 }{25 q}\left(5 q^3+\sqrt{1-q^2} \left(4 \sqrt{9 q^2+16}-3 \sqrt{16 q^2+9}\right)-5 q\right)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"   "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c=\dfrac{1}{625 q^2 \left(q^2-1\right)}  \left( 3650 q^6-1148 q^4-8 \left(12 \sqrt{9 q^2+16} \sqrt{16 q^2+9}+613\right) q^2+20 \sqrt{1-q^2} \left(33 \sqrt{9 q^2+16}+19 \sqrt{16 q^2+9}\right) q+96 \sqrt{9 q^2+16} \sqrt{16 q^2+9}+20 \sqrt{1-q^2} \left(17 \sqrt{9 q^2+16}+31 \sqrt{16 q^2+9}\right) q^3-2598 \right) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"   "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d=-\dfrac{4}{125 q^3 \left(q^2-1\right)^2}  \left(25 q^7-76 q^5+35 \sqrt{1-q^2} \left(\sqrt{16 q^2+9}-2 \sqrt{9 q^2+16}\right) q^2+\left(2 \sqrt{9 q^2+16} \sqrt{16 q^2+9}+99\right) q+5 \sqrt{1-q^2} \left(3 \sqrt{16 q^2+9}-4 \sqrt{9 q^2+16}\right)+5 \sqrt{1-q^2} \left(6 \sqrt{9 q^2+16}-\sqrt{16 q^2+9}\right) q^4-2 \left(\sqrt{9 q^2+16} \sqrt{16 q^2+9}+24\right) q^3\right)  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e= \dfrac{1}{625 q^4 \left(q^2-1\right)^2} \left(    625 q^8-1350 q^6+2 \left(52 \sqrt{9 q^2+16} \sqrt{16 q^2+9}+2549\right) q^2-500 \sqrt{1-q^2} \left(\sqrt{9 q^2+16}+\sqrt{16 q^2+9}\right) q+500 \sqrt{1-q^2} \left(\sqrt{9 q^2+16}+\sqrt{16 q^2+9}\right) q^5-\left(200 \sqrt{9 q^2+16} \sqrt{16 q^2+9}+1873\right) q^4-20 \sqrt{1-q^2} \left(33 \sqrt{9 q^2+16}+19 \sqrt{16 q^2+9}\right) q^3+625             \right) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"then solve for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0= 2^{2/3} a^2 \sqrt[3]{\sqrt{\left(27 \left(a d^2+b^2 e\right)-9 c (8 a e+b d)+2 c^3\right)^2-4 \left(12 a e-3 b d+c^2\right)^3}-72 a c e+27 a d^2+27 b^2 e-9 b c d+2 c^3}+\frac{2 \sqrt[3]{2} a^2 \left(12 a e-3 b d+c^2\right)}{\sqrt[3]{\sqrt{\left(27 \left(a d^2+b^2 e\right)-9 c (8 a e+b d)+2 c^3\right)^2-4 \left(12 a e-3 b d+c^2\right)^3}-72 a c e+27 a d^2+27 b^2 e-9 b c d+2 c^3}}+\frac{3 \sqrt{3} a \left(8 a^2 d-4 a b c+b^3\right)}{\sqrt{2\ 2^{2/3} a \sqrt[3]{\sqrt{\left(27 \left(a d^2+b^2 e\right)-9 c (8 a e+b d)+2 c^3\right)^2-4 \left(12 a e-3 b d+c^2\right)^3}-72 a c e+27 a d^2+27 b^2 e-9 b c d+2 c^3}+\frac{4 \sqrt[3]{2} a \left(12 a e-3 b d+c^2\right)}{\sqrt[3]{\sqrt{\left(27 \left(a d^2+b^2 e\right)-9 c (8 a e+b d)+2 c^3\right)^2-4 \left(12 a e-3 b d+c^2\right)^3}-72 a c e+27 a d^2+27 b^2 e-9 b c d+2 c^3}}-8 a c+3 b^2}}+8 a^2 c-3 a b^2   "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

title: 18 - 24 - 30 triangle
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/solvable/7ecb5d07f2.31f2f15d55.4r3IgA.png?width=250"}},{"type":"text","text":"\nWhat is the area of a triangle with side lengths 18, 24, and 30?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"From the side lengths 18, 24, and 30,
we can see that it forms the ratio of 3:4:5"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence, we can deduce that this is a right angled triangle, with 18 and 24 forming the right angle.
To find the area, we do (18*24)/2=216 and we get the answer."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since the lengths of the triangle have a GCF not equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" then we can reduce it by the principle of similar triangles, this would give us the "simplest" lengths of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(9, 12, 15)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". 
There are several approaches you can work on, here are some:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(1) Since the lengths satisfy the pythagorean relation, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^{2} + b^{2} = c^{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we can proceed to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A = (1/2)(bh)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with the two shorter sides be base or height."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A = (1/2)(9)(12)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A = 54"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and since the side ratio of the original triangle and the simplest triangle, the ratios of their areas is equal to its square, thus, "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A = 54(4) = 216"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(2) Since we were given lengths of sides of the triangle, we can use Heron's Formula:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A = \sqrt{(s)(s - a)(s - b)(s - c)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"s"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the semi perimeter of the triangle."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"s = (1/2)(18 + 24+ 30)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"s = 9 + 12 + 15"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"s = 36"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A = \sqrt{(36)(36 - 18)(36 - 24)(36 - 30)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A = \sqrt{6^{6}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A = 216"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Which agrees with (1)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=18,b=24,c=30
Area=Sqrt[s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c) where 2s=a+b+c
s=36, s-a=18, s-b=12, s-c=6
Area= sqrt[36x18x12x6]= sqrt[6x6x6x3x6x2x6]=6x6x6=216"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"we can do it by either the herons formula or the simple formula... 
both ways, the area is 216"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Clearly "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"24^2+18^2=30^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence it is a Right-angled Triangle"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, Area = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{2}\times base\times height = \frac{1}{2}\times 18\times 24 = 216"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"18 , 24 , 30 is a triangle , then by divide all by 6 we get 3 , 4 , 5 as we know these lengths belong to Right-angled triangle , then area of that triangle will be 
( 1/2 * 24 ) * 18 = 216 
answer is = 216"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"by heorn's formula :_ [s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)]^1/2  we get"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"semi perimeter (S):_ a+b+c/2 (where a,b,c are lengths of sides of triangle)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"30+18+24/2= 36"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"by the heron's formula :- put the value of s 'a'b'c "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"area of triangle is :_ [36(36-18)(36-24)(36-30)]^1/2 = 216"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Sum of cubes of n consecutive natural number is given by (n(n+1)/2)^2.
Therefore,answer=3025."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hello,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"as 1+8+27+......................+1000, it is actually n^(3) for n=[1,10]....."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 = 1x1x1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8 = 2x2x2"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"27 = 3x3x3 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"64 = 4x4x4 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"125 = 5x5x5 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"216 = 6x6x6"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"343 = 7x7x7"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"512 = 8x8x8"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"729 = 9x9x9"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1000 =  10x10x10"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore,by adding 1+8+27+64+125+216+343+512+729+1000=3025...."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1^3 +2^3 +3^3 +.........+n^3 = ((n(n+1)/2))^2
Thus n=10 implies,
10*11/2 * 10 *11/2 = 3025"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1^3 +2^3+...+n^3=(1+2+3+...+n)^2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=10 \Rightarrow 1^3+2^3+...+10^3=( \frac{10\cdot 11}{2})^2=\boxed{3025} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Two unit squares, black and blue, are inscribed inside a trapezoid. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/0WoS6B3lEH-sangaku-maximum-c-021920.jpg?width=400"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The black square shares a right angle corner and left side with the trapezoid.  The blue square is rotated in such a way as to maximize the length of the vertical right side (purple) of the trapezoid. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This length can be expressed as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+\sqrt{a\sqrt{b} - c} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are square-free positive integers.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the sum "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b+c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let us define the tilting angle as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and let us mark vertices "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"D"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"E"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" as in figure below. Let us also call the purple side as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/utLUXTeCTT-sem-titulo.jpg?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We will have:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \large \displaystyle y = 1 + \overline{DE} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Notice also that:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \large \displaystyle  \overline{BC} = \cos(x) + \sin(x) - 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \large \displaystyle  \overline{AB} = 1 + \cos(x)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \large \displaystyle  \overline{AD} = \cos(x) + \sin(x) + 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Triangles "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Delta ABC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Delta ADE"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are similar, so:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \large \displaystyle \frac{\overline{DE}}{\overline{BC}} =  \frac{\overline{AD}}{\overline{AB}} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \large \displaystyle \overline{DE} = \frac{ (\cos(x) + \sin(x) -1)(\cos(x) + \sin(x) + 1)}{1 + \cos(x)} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \large \displaystyle \overline{DE} = \frac{ (\cos(x) + \sin(x))^2 - 1}{1 + \cos(x)} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \large \displaystyle \overline{DE} = \frac{ \sin(2x)}{1 + \cos(x)} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \color{#20A900} \boxed { \large \displaystyle y  = 1 + \frac{ \sin(2x)}{1 + \cos(x)} } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Differentiating "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with respect to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and making it equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":":"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \large \displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{2\cos(2x) (1 + \cos(x)) - \sin(2x) ( -\sin(x) ) }{ (1+\cos(x))^2 } = 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \large \displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{ 2 (2\cos^2(x)-1) (1 + \cos(x)) + 2\sin^2(x) \cos(x) }{ (1+\cos(x))^2 } = 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \large \displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{ 2 (2\cos^2(x)-1) (1 + \cos(x)) + 2( 1 - \cos^2(x) ) \cos(x) }{ (1+\cos(x))^2 } = 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0 \leq x \leq \frac{\pi}{2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 + \cos(x) \neq 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". So:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \large \displaystyle \cos^3(x) +2\cos^2(x) -1  = 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \large \displaystyle (\cos(x) + 1)(\cos^2(x) + \cos(x) -1) = 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \cos(x) = -1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is impossible since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0 \leq x \leq \frac{\pi}{2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The other two solutions are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \cos(x) = - \frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2} \approx -1.618"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is also impossible, and:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \color{#20A900} \boxed { \large \displaystyle \cos(x) = \frac{ \sqrt{5} - 1}{2} } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Which leads to:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \color{#20A900} \boxed { \large \displaystyle \sin(x) = \frac{ \sqrt{2\sqrt{5} - 2 }}{2} } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \displaystyle y  = 1 + \frac{ \sin(2x)}{1 + \cos(x)} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \displaystyle y  = 1 + \frac{ 2\sin(x)\cos(x)}{1 + \cos(x)} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \displaystyle y  = 1 + \frac{ \left ( \sqrt{2\sqrt{5} - 2} \right )(\sqrt{5} - 1)}{\sqrt{5} + 1} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Multiplying above and below by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \sqrt{5} - 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":":"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \displaystyle y  = 1 + \frac{ \left ( \sqrt{2\sqrt{5} - 2} \right )(6 - 2\sqrt{5})}{4} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \displaystyle y  = 1 + \frac{ \sqrt{( 2\sqrt{5} - 2)(6 - 2\sqrt{5})^2}}{4} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \displaystyle y  = 1 + \frac{ \sqrt{160\sqrt{5} - 352}}{\sqrt{16} } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#20A900} \boxed{ \large \displaystyle y  = 1 +  \sqrt{10\sqrt{5} - 22} } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \color{#3D99F6} \large \displaystyle a= 10, b = 5, c = 22 \rightarrow \boxed{\large \displaystyle a+b+c = 37} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Draw in these lines and label the diagram as follows:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/uploads/jnspjClxM9-1846sangakau.gif"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"From right "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\triangle HCG"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"GH = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"CG = \sin \theta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"CH = \cos \theta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  By symmetry, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"CG = HI = EJ = FK = \sin \theta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"CH = EI = FJ = GK = \cos \theta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\triangle AME \sim \triangle ANL"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" by AA symmetry, so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{LN}{AN} = \frac{EM}{AM}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  Letting "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y = LK"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"LN = LK - NK = y - 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AN = CD + CG + KG = \sin \theta + \cos \theta + 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"EM = BI = CH + HI - BC = \sin \theta + \cos \theta - 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AM = AB + BM = AB + EI = \sin \theta + 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Substituting these into the ratio gives "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{y - 1}{\sin \theta + \cos \theta + 1} = \frac{\sin \theta + \cos \theta - 1}{\sin \theta + 1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which simplifies to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y = \frac{2 \sin \theta \cos \theta}{\sin \theta + 1} + 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The maximum of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y = LK"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" occurs when the derivative "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y'"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is zero, therefore, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y' = \frac{2(1 + \sin \theta)(\cos^2 \theta - \sin^2 \theta) - 2 \sin \theta \cos^2 \theta}{(\sin \theta + 1)^2} = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  Using the identity "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\cos^2 \theta = 1 - \sin^2 \theta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", this simplifies to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(\sin \theta + 1)(\sin^2 \theta + \sin \theta - 1) = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which has one positive solution of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sin \theta = \frac{\sqrt{5} - 1}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This makes "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\cos \theta = \sqrt{1 - \sin^2 \theta} = \sqrt{\frac{\sqrt{5} - 1}{2}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which makes the maximum of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"LK"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y = \frac{2 \sin \theta \cos \theta}{\sin \theta + 1} + 1 = 1 + \sqrt{10\sqrt{5} - 22}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a = 10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b = 5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c = 22"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a + b + c = \boxed{37}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let the angle of bottom left side of right square as x, determine the slope M(x) of inclined line of trapezoid:
M=[{(2^0.5)sin(x+pi/4)-1}/{1+cos(x)-(2^0.5)cos(x+pi/4)}],
and the vertical right side H of trapezoid:
H=[1+{1+sin(x)+cos(x)}M]. Maximum of H(x) gives H=1+[10{(5)^0.5}-22]^0.5.
Therefore, a+b+c=10+5+22
Answer=37"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: Circus Performer
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Bobo the Clown wants to cross a bridge over dangerous waters while performing a three ring juggle, in which one or two rings are in the air at all times. The bridge can support a maximum weight of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\SI[per-mode=symbol]{1000}{\newton},"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" above which it will collapse. Each ring weighs "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\SI[per-mode=symbol]{100}{\newton}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and Bobo himself weighs "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\SI[per-mode=symbol]{800}{\newton}."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/SNmzl4uz9Z-juggling-clown.svg?width=450"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Coco the Clown tells Bobo that it will be safe to cross the bridge as long as Bobo is "},{"type":"text","text":"never","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" holding all three rings at once. Dodo the Clown disagrees, arguing that the juggle will collapse the bridge, even if at least one ring is in the air at all times."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Who is correct, Coco or Dodo?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"As the problem states, Bobo alternates between moments where he has one or two rings in his hands."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Coco claims the bridge will stay intact as long as Bobo never holds three rings simultaneously, which implies that in the periods when two rings contact Bobo's hands, they can't ever require more than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\SI{200}{\newton}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to support."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let's consider one of the moments where Bobo goes from holding two rings to holding one ring, by throwing one ring up into the air.
In order to simply hold a ring, Bobo (and therefore the bridge) has to oppose the pull of gravity by providing a support force of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m_\textrm{ring}g = W_\textrm{ring} = \SI{100}{\newton}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" upward. 
To throw a ring upward, Bobo must accelerate it upward with acceleration "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a > g"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which means he (and ultimately the bridge) must provide a force "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F = ma > mg = W_\textrm{ring}."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, in the moment that Bobo tosses one of the rings upward, the total force the bridge must support is 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned}
F_\textrm{total throw} &= W_\textrm{Bobo} + W_\textrm{ring} + ma \\
&\gt  W_\textrm{Bobo} + W_\textrm{ring} + W_\textrm{ring} \\
&= \SI{1000}{\newton}
\end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
which shows that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F_\textrm{total throw} > \SI{1000}{\newton}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and the bridge will collapse due to the juggle."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, consider the case where Bobo perfectly times the catch of the incoming ring with the upward throw of the other.
In this case, things are even worse!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"To decelerate the incoming ring, Bobo has to accelerate it upward with acceleration "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d > g"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (or else it would still be accelerating downward!), and therefore provide a force upward given by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F_\textrm{catch} = md > mg."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
Thus, both "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F_\textrm{catch}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F_\textrm{throw}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" require upward force in excess of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"W_\textrm{ring},"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and the bridge will have to support even more force than in the case we analyzed above."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Alex Li – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Acceleration is velocity divided by time. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            No, he's saying that there are 2 rings in the air at all times. It doesn't seem implausible. I will try here. For this situation to be plausible, Bobo must throw a ring in the air for exactly half the time that it is the air (since there are 3 rings, they must each be in the air twice as long as in the hand)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"How long is a ring going to be in the air? We know that position must equal 0 when it lands. Using kinematics (and g = 10)..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" position = 0 = F_\textrm{toss} * t - 5t^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"t_\textrm{in air} = F_\textrm{toss} / 5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(The 0 root is the start of the throw, and we only care about the second root.)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, since this time is twice the time to apply the force, we have that "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"t_\textrm{to throw} = 2 * F_\textrm{toss} / 5 =  F_\textrm{toss} / 2.5  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, we have to relate the time to throw to the amount of upwards force. F = ma. Thankfully, the optimal scenario is constant downwards acceleration, so I can replace acceleration with velocity times time, saying"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F_\textrm{toss} = mv_\textrm{final}t"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"However, note that the force of the toss is half that of the actual force, since slowing a falling ring will take as long as much force as throwing it back up."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F_\textrm{toss}/2 = m * v_\textrm{final} * t_\textrm{to throw}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Okay, now we have the equations, so let's do math.  Substituting for t..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F_\textrm{toss}/2 = mv_\textrm{final} * (F_\textrm{toss} / 2.5)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5/4 = mv_\textrm{final} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"With a mass of 100..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5/400 = 1/80 = v_\textrm{final} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Yay, equation! But, eh, what does it mean? Well, simply put, if Bobo throws his rings up in the air such that their velocity is equal to 1/80 meters per second or less, then he can, actually, make it across the bridge. Is this realistic? Well, with an upwards velocity of 1/80, we're expecting each ring to be in the air (by the above equation) for about 1/400 seconds. Which means each throw takes place in 1/800 seconds. So, if Bobo can manage 800 carefully balanced throws in a second, while walking across the bridge, he can, actually, get across with 3 rings using your strategy.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            So basically, you're suggesting he throw two rings in the air, and run across the bridge so that he doesn't catch them until he crosses the bridge?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

I mean, I guess I don't really have to worry about that so much because I am only learning how to write good solutions, but I guess the moral of the story is that the main purpose of the discussions is to communicate our ideas and to learn something new from all of it, not so much to argue about who's right and who's wrong or to show off your intelligence to other people. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"And to be perfectly honest, I feel as though most of these "smart" people tend to use their intelligence or just learn stuff they're probably never going to use as a means of showing off rather than learning about the world due to its beauty and magnificence. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            When I joined the discussion I wasn't trying to criticise you personally.  I genuinely didn't understand what you were trying to say and I wanted you to explain further.  Your solution concentrated on the motion of the juggling ring.  You seemed to imply that when the ring was accelerating it produced a force that caused the bridge to collapse, without explaining how that force was transmitted downwards onto the bridge.  When I asked you to explain further you kept talking about the speed of the ring, but what I was trying to understand, was the forces on the bridge that would caused it to collapse.  I knew that the ring was being accelerated upwards by Bobo throwing it into the air, but what I forgot was that when the ring was being accelerated upwards, Bobo was accelerating downwards, thus increasing his 'weight' or downwards thrust, onto the bridge.
In order to throw the ring into the air, Bobo had to push downwards onto the bridge and it was that downward push that collapsed the bridge.
Discussing problems can be useful and lead to a more complete understanding of the solution.  Although I found our discussion confusing, it did help me to think more clearly.  When Josh posted his solution with the equations, describing the forces involved, I was eventually able to understand what was going on.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If so, sorry, I'm kind of new with this.

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Yes that makes sense.  Thank you for clarifying that.  When I said he he was pushing down onto the bridge, he is actually accelerating his body downwards and although his mass does not increase, the force he is exerting on the bridge is increasing.  Which produces the extra force needed to throw the ring into the air and to catch the other ring when it falls into his hand.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Coco is not correct.  Once Dodo is holding two rings, he and the two rings are at 1000 N.  And at that same moment, as he launches
the third ring upward, he has just increased his effective weight downward, beyond 1000 N.  The bridge collapses.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                    "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Relevant wiki: Newton's Second Law","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"According to Newton's Second Law of Motion, an object's net force is the result of its change of momentum over time. Suppose that Bobo throws one of the three rings 1 meter high. If that were the case, then v"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"^{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" = 0 + 2(10)(1), which means that the final velocity is approximately 4.5 m/s. The momentum of one of the rings would then be the mass of the ring (Newtons divided by g) multiplied by 4.5 m/s, 10 kg times 4.5 m/s, or 45 "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{kg * m}{s}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". If it took 0.2 seconds for Bobo to catch the ring, then the amount of downward force exerted by the ring would then be 225 N. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This same problem can also be solved by considering Newton's Third Law of motion. According to Newton's Thrid Law of Motion, for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. In order for Bobo to throw any of the three rings into the air, he must apply a force that is higher than the upward force of one of the rings themselves. This creates a larger downward push on him than if he had just carried the rings across, causing the bridge to collapse."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Deva Craig – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" I find your solution good. No matter what values you plug in, the bridge will break if Bobo throws or catch a ring on the bridge. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Kevin Quigg – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Sorry about that, I've confused the two in the explanation. What I meant to say was that the velocity would be zero at that point. I probably should have never written a solution to this problem because I'm so horrible at it and I'm making your more confused! I really wanted to help you understand what's going on! "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Deva Craig – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" No! When the ring stops in its path the velocity is 0 (by definition). The ring reaches its maximum upward velocity when it leaves Bobo's hand. The ring only accelerates upwards when it is in Bobo's hand. Once Bobo releases the ring there is no upward force on the ring and its upward acceleration will cease, it will however accelerate downwards due to gravity. It will still travel upwards, but its velocity will decrease until it reaches zero, then it will travel downwards. The amount of time is not arbitrary. The amount of time it spends in the air is determined by the velocity it has when it leaves Bobo's hand, this determines how high it will travel and the time it takes to reach its maximum height can be calculated. Similarly the amount of time it takes to fall back into Bobo's hand can also be calculated. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Kevin Quigg – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Once again, you're confusing the values I've found for average values, the values I've really found (The 225 Newtons and 4.5 m/s) were the final values, the values of the force and velocity when Bobo catches the rings, 225 Newtons is not the amount of force Bobo exerts on the ring as he throws it, and 4.5 m/s is the final velocity, in other words, the velocity of the ring when it stops in its path. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Also, you have to keep in mind that an object does NOT always need to change its mass in order for its net force to change. Mass is not the only factor that determines how much net force an object has while it's in motion. Net force can also change if the acceleration changes, but the mass remains constant as demonstrated in Newton's famous equation F=ma. Another way an object's Net Force is determined is if we find the change in momentum and divide it by how much time it takes for the object to stay in the air, which is in fact where we can derive Newton's famous equation in the first place. In other words, how an object's net force changes depends on the circumstances. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let's take this problem for example. Before Bobo throws a ring in the air, the only force acting on the ring right now is the force of the pull of the earth due to gravity. When Bobo throws a ring there are two forces acting on the ring. There's (1) The force of the pull of the earth due to gravity and (2) The upward force exerted by Bobo to make the ring get in the air in the first place. The latter force is known as an applied force, a force which is put on an object through the application of a push or pull on it. The value of the latter force will decrease due to the acceleration of the ring as it makes its trip. At one point though, the total velocity of the ring will be zero. That is when the ring reaches its maximum height. After that, the force you've already put on the ring becomes a downward force since it is still decreasing due to acceleration, which therefore increases the total downward force of the object."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let's also talk about the amount of time I've used to prove the solution to this problem. The reason why the amount of time would be arbitrary would be because the amount of time doesn't really change the fact that downward force would increase. That downward force is really the result of the acceleration of the force of the pull of the earth due to gravity. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Kevin Quigg – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" When the clown catches the ring, the ring pushes on him with a force greater than its weight. That is why the ring deaccelerates and stops in the hands of the clown. This extra force is transferred to the bridge through the legs of the clown and the bridge collapses. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Deva Craig – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Yes when Bobo throws the ring up into the air he pushes down onto the bridge with the same force. But he is generating that force using the weight of his own body. If he throws the ring with 225N, as you say in your answer, he also pushes down onto the bridge with 225N, But that 225N is part of the 800N that he has by virtue of his mass and the force of gravity acting on his body. He is only re distributing his own weight. He can NOT generate extra mass in order to throw the ring into the air. He can only use the weight that he has. There is NO extra force. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Kevin Quigg – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Remember that Newton's Third Law states that for every action, there is an equal but opposite reaction. When Bobo throws a ring, a downward force is also be exerted on him, which exceeds the 1000 N limit. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I am still confused, the only force acting on the bridge is the weight of the clown and the rings due to gravity.  When the ring is pushed up into the air the clown can only use his own weight to push the ring upwards.  When the ring falls back down it is falling under gravity.  If the clown only has two rings in his hand at any one time there is only1000N pushing down on the bridge.  There are no extra forces!

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            The problem here seems to be that you mistook the velocity I found as the average velocity of the ring. In reality, the velocity I found was the final velocity. I didn't make that clear in my original solution, sorry! The final velocity squared is calculated by adding the initial velocity squared onto the product of twice the acceleration and the displacement of the ring. We need to find the final velocity of the ring in order to find the momentum of the same ring when Bobo catches it, which is directly proportional to the velocity of the ring.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

The position and speed of the rings along with the forces acting on the bridge can be calculated using the laws of physics, you cannot just pull numbers out of a hat!

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2n+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is always odd for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \in \mathbb{N}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{\left( 2n+1 \right)}^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is also odd."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence, the appropriate choice is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{\text{Sometimes Odd and Sometimes Even}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            You used a condition of "provided there are no dominos that lie both in the outer and middle ring (same goes with both the middle and inner ring)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"As such, you need to deal with cases where this happens. It is possible to have 1 domino block the outer+middle ring, and another to block the middle+inner ring. Why isn't the resultant configuration unique?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The rest of your argument makes sense.

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            First analyse the Problem."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It is evident that if you can isolate out a complete 2 x 2 square, there are at least two ways of filling it up, either both dominos horizontally or both vertically."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider the whole board as 3 rings. Observe the outermost ring of squares alone. For all of them to be filled, there are two ways (symmetrical), provided there are no dominos that lie both in the outer and middle ring. Same goes with both the middle and inner ring. Therefore the dominos that must be placed must restrict a block lying in two rings and ensure that any two adjacent rings have blocks that do not form a 2 x 2 square, that is, adjacent rings do not have same configuration.
This implies that there must be one block in every ring (forcing the rest of the dominos to fall in one of the two possibilities of that ring) and the block must be arranged such that no squares are formed between the rings. This gives the minimum number of blocks as 3."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Lets take a case when a domino lies across two rings. Now analyse each ring. It is evident that it can’t be filled. To be able to fill a ring, an even number of dominos must lie across it. If we keep two dominos across the outer and middle ring, then the outer ring is now fixed. However, the middle ring and outer ring now have the same configuration. Any piece now placed in the outer or inner ring will form squares. To force the middle ring to a different configuration, you would need at least 2 (or an even number of) dominos on either side of the domino placed .To minimize this, you can keep the former dominos adjacent, requiring only 2 (or an even number of) dominos for middle and inner ring. However, placing dominos across rings in some case may make the board unsolvable. In other cases, there would be the formation of squares which would make the not fit the solution."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, the least possible number of dominos only comes when the initial dominos are arranged along the rings. The answer is 3. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Eg."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X X O O O O.....O X X O O O.....O O X X O O"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"O X X O O O.....O X O O O O.....O X X O O O"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"O O X X O O.....O X X O O O.....O O O O O O"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"O O O O O O.....O O X O O O.....O O X X O O"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"O O O O O O.....O O O O O O.....O O O O O O"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"O O O O O O.....O O O O O O.....O O O O O O"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"And many more...

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            For construction problems like this, it is useful to think in terms of a "structure-avoider" and "structure-finder". Try and express what would make a unique covering, which would help explain why "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k=1, 2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" will not work.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Calvin, thanks for the comment.  I agree the statement is a bit undermining the whole thing.  Actually, I tried a few 2 dominos combination before deducing that it won't lead to continuous pocket generations.  But, I just can't put it mathematically, ... I'm embarrassed to say that what I did was trial error and deduce bravely.  I'd like to say that I don't need to try a lot, I just need to make sure that the first domino will be in the upper left quadrant, for instance ...

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Pockets are a way to see uniqueness. However, in dealing with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k=2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", my sense is that there are too many cases to work around. Also, the "it's easy to see by trying a few combinations  ..." is not a rigorous statement. Can you add more detail?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                            Another example:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"codeBlock","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x.....
xx....
.xx...
..x...
......
......
"}],"attrs":[{"text":"x.....
xx....
.xx...
..x...
......
......
","language":null}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Basically, the idea is to find a structure of dominoes which leads to the the existence of "pockets", (a pocket means an unoccupied cell with exactly one unoccupied neighbor).  A pocket will force domino to occupy its place with exactly one way ... the above structure will force one domino after another to be placed to cover the pockets."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" won't give us any pockets regardless where we put the domino."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k = 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", to create pockets, at least one domino has to be touching the edge of the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6 \times 6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" area, or else, there will be no pockets created.  It's easy to see by trying a few combinations of 2 dominoes that the pocket generation will stop after a few moves.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}
